clean_story: Instant eye reshaping.  Camouflage without color. "Squid" comes from the Greek teuthis, meaning "squid," but their eyes work like built-in projectors—adjusting shape to control light, not just see it. Most animals change pupil size to manage brightness. Squid do that and warp their entire eye’s curvature—like a camera lens zooming in, but with muscle. Their pupils stretch into W-shapes, slits, or dumbbells, scattering light to hide their silhouette from predators below. Here’s how:Ring-shaped muscles around the iris contract asymmetrically, pulling the pupil into jagged edges. This breaks up their dark eye-spot, making them nearly invisible against sunlight filtering down. Caribbean reef squid use this to hunt—flashing W-pupils to signal mates while staying hidden from barracuda. Lab tests show pupil shifts take under 200 milliseconds—faster than a human blink. No bones, no rigid parts: pure muscular hydrostatics, like a water balloon changing shape by squeezing its sides. Three related subjects are cephalopod skin pixels, polarized light hunting, and soft robotics mimicry.
